hints_html: Solving the equation \(f'(x) = 0\) will be similar to the previous question - you’ll want to know the values of \(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\) at certain angles. However the answer will be different from before - how is this equation different than the previous equation?
hints_latex:
Solving the equation $f'(x) = 0$ will be similar to the previous
question - you'll want to know the values of $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ at
certain angles. However the answer will be different from before - how
is this equation different than the previous equation?
hints_raw: Solving the equation <math>f '(x) = 0</math> will be similar to the previous question - you'll want to know the values of <math>\sin x</math> and <math>\cos x</math> at certain angles.  However the answer will be different from before - how is this equation different than the previous equation?
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
This question is similar to the previous one, except we are using the derivative:

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = \cos x - (-\sin x) = \cos x + \sin x\)

Setting this equal to zero and moving a term over gives

\(\sin x = - \cos x\) (or \(\cos x = -\sin x\))

This means that \(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\) must have equal values but opposite signs. On the unit circle, \(\cos \theta\) corresponds to x-values and \(\sin \theta\) corresponds to y-values, so the opposite signs place us in quadrant II of the coordinate plane (the restriction of \([0, \pi)\) rules out quadrant IV). The angle where the values of \(\sin \theta\) and \(\cos \theta\) are equal in this quadrant is \(3\pi/4\), so \(x = 3\pi/4\).
sols_latex:
This question is similar to the previous one, except we are using the
derivative:

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \cos x - (-\sin x) = \cos x + \sin x$

Setting this equal to zero and moving a term over gives

$\sin x = - \cos x$ (or $\cos x = -\sin x$)

This means that $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ must have equal values but
opposite signs. On the unit circle, $\cos \theta$ corresponds to
x-values and $\sin \theta$ corresponds to y-values, so the opposite
signs place us in quadrant II of the coordinate plane (the restriction
of $[0, \pi)$ rules out quadrant IV). The angle where the values of
$\sin \theta$ and $\cos \theta$ are equal in this quadrant is $3\pi/4$,
so $x = 3\pi/4$.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_7ab_unit_circle.jpg}
sols_raw:
This question is similar to the previous one, except we are using the derivative:

<math>\displaystyle f'(x) = \cos x - (-\sin x) = \cos x + \sin x</math>

Setting this equal to zero and moving a term over gives

<math>\sin x = - \cos x</math> (or <math>\cos x = -\sin x</math>)

This means that <math>\sin x</math> and <math>\cos x</math> must have equal values but opposite signs.  On the unit circle, <math>\cos \theta</math> corresponds to x-values and <math>\sin \theta</math> corresponds to y-values, so the opposite signs place us in quadrant II of the coordinate plane (the restriction of <math>[0, \pi)</math> rules out quadrant IV).  The angle where the values of <math>\sin \theta</math> and <math>\cos \theta</math> are equal in this quadrant is <math>3\pi/4</math>, so <math>x = 3\pi/4</math>.

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 7ab unit circle.jpg|400px]]
statement_html:
Let \(f(x)=\sin x-\cos x\).

Find all values of \(x\) satisfying the equation \(\displaystyle f'(x)=0\) in the interval \([0,\pi)\). Justify your answer.
statement_latex:
Let $f(x)=\sin x-\cos x$.

Find all values of $x$ satisfying the equation $\displaystyle f'(x)=0$
in the interval $[0,\pi)$. Justify your answer.
statement_raw:
Let <math>f(x)=\sin x-\cos x</math>.

Find all values of <math>x</math> satisfying the equation <math>\displaystyle f'(x)=0</math> in the interval <math>[0,\pi)</math>. Justify your answer.
